study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of home-based exercise (dosed walking) compared to monitored bicycle ergometer exercise in improving exercise tolerance, lipid profiles, and quality of life in post-coronary bypass patients.
results_summary: The study found that home-based walking improved exercise tolerance, lipid concentrations, reduced obesity, decreased depression severity, and enhanced quality of life, similar to monitored bicycle exercise. However, overall adherence to physical rehabilitation programs remained low regardless of the type.
population_specificity: 67 men under 75 years old with ischemic heart disease who had undergone coronary bypass surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of standardized psychomotor examination in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) and compare their psychomotor profiles with healthy controls, including walking as one of the assessed variables.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in walking between MDD patients and healthy controls, with MDD patients exhibiting poorer rhythmic adaptation and slowness in global motor skills. Walking was among the psychomotor variables that predicted an MDD diagnosis.
population_specificity: 25 patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) and 25 age- and sex-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a neuromuscular exercise intervention could acutely affect knee joint sounds (amplitude and median power frequency) during activities of daily living, including walking, in individuals with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise intervention led to higher median power frequency (MPF) differences compared to placebo, particularly during walking at the patella, and lower amplitude differences, suggesting potential therapy effects. However, no significant differences were observed in MPF or amplitude during walking and descending stairs at the tibia.
population_specificity: 18 participants with knee osteoarthritis (aged 51.8 ± 7.3 years; 14 females).

study_goal: To determine if the 30-s sit-to-stand (30STS) test can estimate and stratify peak oxygen uptake (VO2peak) and 6-min walking distance (6MWD) in women with breast cancer.
results_summary: The 30STS test showed moderate correlations with relative VO2peak and 6MWD, and weak correlation with absolute VO2peak, suggesting it is a useful tool for estimating functional capacity when CPET or 6MWT are unavailable.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-70 with early-stage breast cancer under treatment with anthracycline and/or anti-HER2 antibodies.

study_goal: To examine the extent to which international clinical and treatment guidelines on post-stroke treatment mention the role of acupuncture and identify what symptoms, including walking, they recommend for its use.
results_summary: The study found that acupuncture received positive recommendations for walking as part of post-stroke rehabilitation in guidelines from 11 countries, indicating its perceived efficacy in this context. However, 35 guidelines from 18 countries made no mention of acupuncture for walking or other symptoms.
population_specificity: Stroke patients in 27 countries (guidelines reviewed from 2001-2021).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 6-month multicomponent exercise training (MCT) on nutritional status and whether it differentially impacts body composition and physical fitness in older adults with decreased functional capacity based on their nutritional status.
results_summary: The study investigated the impact of MCT on nutritional status, body composition, and physical fitness in older adults, but the abstract does not provide specific results regarding these outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 80.4 ± 6.0 years) with decreased functional capacity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a short inpatient electrical muscle stimulation (EMS) intervention on functional capacity and quality of life in severely deconditioned heart failure patients over a 1-month follow-up.
results_summary: EMS significantly improved 6-minute walking test distance, Duke Activity Status Index, and Minnesota Living with Heart Failure Questionnaire scores at discharge, with sustained improvements in quality of life and activity status after 1 month compared to sham stimulation.
population_specificity: Severely deconditioned patients hospitalized for decompensated systolic heart failure (58% men, mean age 66.4±10.2 years).
study_duration: Intervention duration was during hospitalization (exact days not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of home-based cardiac rehabilitation (including walking) versus traditional outpatient rehabilitation in improving cardiac function and quality of life for AMI patients post-PCI.
results_summary: Home rehabilitation significantly improved walking compliance, 6-minute walking test results, and reduced cardiac events compared to outpatient rehabilitation, with no deaths reported in either group.
population_specificity: 80 AMI patients post-PCI, divided into control (outpatient rehab) and observation (home rehab) groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of intravenous and oral iron supplements for treating iron deficiency in heart failure patients, focusing on outcomes like mortality, hospitalization, and functional capacity (measured via the six-minute walking test).
results_summary: Intravenous iron improved exercise capacity (6MWT) and quality of life (KCCQ) but did not reduce mortality. Oral iron reduced hospitalizations and all-cause death but had no significant effect on 6MWT or KCCQ.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure and iron deficiency.
study_duration: At least 12 weeks for significant effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a wearable activity tracker-based exercise training program on cardiac function and physical activity in cystic fibrosis patients.
results_summary: The study found that the exercise training program improved 6-minute walking distance by 20.6%, enhanced right ventricular systolic and diastolic function, and reduced pulmonary artery systolic pressure. Significant correlations were observed between step count and improvements in cardiac function.
population_specificity: 42 stable cystic fibrosis patients (aged 16.8 ± 3.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy of exercise interventions, including walking, on muscle strength, muscle mass, and physical performance in older adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The study found that exercise interventions, likely including walking, improved muscle strength, muscle mass, and physical performance in older adults with sarcopenia, as indicated by weighted/standardized mean differences with 95% confidence intervals.
population_specificity: Older adults with sarcopenia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of a physical therapist-led physical activity intervention, including walking, in a nested randomized controlled trial within the Enroll-HD cohort for Huntington's disease (HD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group showed improvements in fitness, walking endurance, and self-reported physical activity compared to the control group, with high adherence and intervention fidelity. However, data completeness varied, and motor and functional decline in the cohort group matched previous studies.
population_specificity: Huntington's disease patients from six specialist centers in Germany, Spain, and the U.S.
effective_dosage: 18 sessions delivered over 12 months (frequency not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic effects of Wuqinxi Qigong versus stretching on gait, motor symptoms, and quality of life in individuals with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The Wuqinxi Qigong group showed increased gait speed, though full results were not detailed in the abstract. Secondary outcomes included assessments of motor symptoms, balance, and quality of life, but specific findings were not provided.
population_specificity: 40 participants with idiopathic mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supervised exercise therapy improves microvascular blood flow in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) by measuring blood flow and oxygenation dynamics during reactive hyperemia.
results_summary: The study compared standard medical care with 3 months of supervised exercise therapy in PAD patients, using MRI to assess blood flow and oxygenation changes. Results suggested exercise may improve claudication symptoms, though the exact mechanism remains unclear.
population_specificity: 148 subjects with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: Supervised exercise therapy (specific frequency/intensity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of local intramuscular transplantation of autologous adult bone marrow mononuclear cells (BMMNCs) as a treatment for critical limb ischaemia (CLI).
results_summary: The study found very low- to low-certainty evidence with no clear effect on mortality, mixed results on pain reduction, and uncertain effects on amputation rates. Limited data showed no clear differences in side effects between BMMNC and control groups.
population_specificity: Participants with a clinical diagnosis of critical limb ischaemia (CLI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 12-week intervention with Rubus idaeus leaf extract on symptoms of knee osteoarthritis, focusing on pain relief and functional improvement.
results_summary: The study found that Rubus idaeus leaf extract (400 mg) significantly reduced pain measured by VAS after 12 weeks, but it did not significantly improve WOMAC pain, stiffness, or physical function subscores compared to placebo. The extract was well tolerated.
population_specificity: 198 participants with femorotibial osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of therapeutic angiogenesis by autologous adipose-derived regenerative cells (ADRCs) implantation in patients with critical limb ischemia (CLI) who had no other treatment options.
results_summary: The study found that ADRCs implantation was safe, with no major adverse events, and effective, with 94.1% of limbs free from major amputation at 6 months and improvements in quality of life and ulcer size. The overall survival rate was 100% at all time points.
population_specificity: Patients with critical limb ischemia (Fontaine class III-IV) who had no other option for standard revascularization therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (freshly isolated autologous ADRCs implantation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of whole-body electromyostimulation (WB-EMS) training and protein supplementation on body composition, physical function, metabolism, and inflammatory biomarkers in middle-aged and elderly patients with sarcopenic obesity (SO).
results_summary: WB-EMS training improved sarcopenia Z-score, waist circumference, skeletal muscle mass index, and appendicular skeletal muscle mass. Protein supplementation reduced body fat percentage and fat mass, and increased grip strength, but neither intervention significantly affected metabolic or inflammatory biomarkers.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly patients with sarcopenic obesity (SO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the interrelationships between gait impairment, cerebral small vessel disease (CSVD), and cognitive impairments in aging, identifying gaps for future research and potential intervention pathways.
results_summary: The study found that adverse gait and cognitive outcomes were linked to widespread CSVD pathologies in the brain, and poor gait and CSVD pathologies were more strongly associated with vascular dementia than Alzheimer's disease-related dementia.
population_specificity: Adults over 65 years, including those with pre-dementia and dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of anti-gravity treadmill gait training and underwater walking therapy on cardiorespiratory fitness, gait, and balance in stroke survivors.
results_summary: Anti-gravity treadmill training significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness, including maximum heart rate, walking distance, and metabolic equivalents, but no significant changes in balance were observed across groups. Underwater walking therapy results were not highlighted in the abstract.
population_specificity: 39 stroke survivors admitted to a center between July 2017 and January 2018.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current technological developments, particularly wearable technology and IoT, for supporting telemonitoring and self-management of freezing of gait (FoG) in people with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study highlights the potential of wearable technology and IoT to complement current therapeutic options for FoG in PD, emphasizing their role in enhancing daily functioning and quality of life through seamless monitoring and self-management in home environments.
population_specificity: People living with Parkinson's disease (PD), specifically those experiencing freezing of gait (FoG).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of different exercise intensities (including walking) on inflammatory markers (IL-6 and TNF-α) and functional outcomes in patients with early knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Brisk walking showed the most significant improvements in functional scores (FMA and ADL) and reductions in inflammatory markers (TNF-α and IL-6) compared to other exercise intensities and the control group. No significant differences in adverse events were observed among the groups.
population_specificity: 131 patients with early knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (groups included static control, walking, brisk walking, and jogging).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative rehabilitation, including walking exercises, improves quality of life in lung transplant candidates.
results_summary: Preoperative rehabilitation improved quality of life, mood status, and reduced dyspnea in lung transplant candidates, with an increase in 6-minute walking distance observed. The interventions included motor and breathing exercises, integrated with education programs.
population_specificity: Adult patients on the active wait list for lung transplant.
effective_dosage: Variable duration (3-20 weeks) and frequency (3-6 times per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and quantify changes in gait parameters after therapeutic interventions in adults with neurologic disorders, focusing on spatiotemporal gait characteristics.
results_summary: Sensory and electrical stimulation significantly improved step length and gait speed in adults with Parkinson’s disease, while conventional physical therapy improved spatial gait parameters in adults with stroke. Balance or physical activity interventions showed mixed effects on gait parameters.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥55 years with neurologic disorders (Parkinson’s disease and stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, functional improvements (including 6-minute walking distance), and mortality rates following transcatheter tricuspid valve replacement in patients with significant tricuspid valve regurgitation.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in 6-minute walking distance (mean difference = 91.1 m) and New York Heart Association functional class after transcatheter tricuspid valve replacement. Mortality rates were non-significantly different from predicted operative mortality.
population_specificity: Patients with severe, massive, or torrential tricuspid valve regurgitation (mean age 75.8 years, high surgical risk).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the effects of acupuncture on chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that acupuncture improved structural regeneration in CIPN, as measured by nerve conduction studies, and led to subjective improvements in symptoms like burning pain, cramps, numbness, and gait unsteadiness.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on acupuncture, not Walking).
study_duration: 10-week treatment period with follow-ups at 14 and 28 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Total Body Recumbent Stepper (TBRS) training on exercise capacity and oxidative stress in COPD patients.
results_summary: TBRS training significantly improved exercise capacity (6MWD), reduced dyspnoea scores (BORG, mMRC), decreased COPD exacerbations, and increased oxidative stress markers (TRXS). No significant changes were observed in pulmonary function parameters.
population_specificity: 90 stable COPD patients (45 in TBRS group, 45 in control group).
effective_dosage: TBRS endurance training three times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of elastic band exercise on pain, kinesiophobia, functional, and psychological status in patients after total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: Elastic band exercise significantly improved pain, functional capacity, psychological status, and reduced fear of movement and depression in patients after total knee arthroplasty, with statistically significant differences observed 4 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: 60 patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the sustained effects of a buddy-style intervention on improving physical activity, specifically outdoor walking and muscle strength exercises, in older adults with disabilities.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly longer outdoor walking time compared to the control group at 24 weeks follow-up, indicating a sustained effect up to 12 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with disabilities attending adult day-care centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the time to arthroplasty in patients with hip and knee osteoarthritis (OA) and identify prognostic factors for progression to surgery.
results_summary: The study found that 46% of hip OA patients and 20% of knee OA patients progressed to arthroplasty within five years, with desire for surgery, walking difficulties, and frequent pain being strong prognostic factors. Comorbidities reduced the likelihood of surgery in hip OA, while being overweight or obese increased it in knee OA.
population_specificity: 72,069 patients with hip and knee OA referred for first-line OA intervention.
study_duration: Follow-up until first primary arthroplasty surgery or December 31, 2016 (study period: May 2008 to December 2016).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and safety of mobility training, including walking, on overall functioning and mobility in frail older people living in the community.
results_summary: High-certainty evidence showed mobility training, including walking, significantly improved mobility levels, with benefits maintained at six months post-intervention. Moderate-certainty evidence suggested functional improvement, though not clinically significant, and little to no difference in falls, nursing care admissions, or death rates.
population_specificity: Frail community-dwelling older adults aged 65+ years.
study_duration: Duration varied across studies; follow-up was assessed up to six months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the quality of life impacts, unmet needs, and treatment outcome priorities for Japanese patients with non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (nmCRPC).
results_summary: The study found that nmCRPC patients frequently reported difficulty walking, among other mobility-related impacts, but did not specifically evaluate walking as an intervention or outcome.
population_specificity: Japanese patients with non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (nmCRPC) and their treating physicians.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of whole-body vibration training (WBVT) on lower limb motor function and neuroplasticity in stroke patients.
results_summary: The study will compare WBVT, routine rehabilitation training, and a control group to assess improvements in lower limb motor function and neural plasticity, with outcomes measured at multiple time points.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with stroke.

study_goal: To examine the efficacy of exercise combined with trigger point acupuncture compared to exercise alone for older patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that exercise combined with trigger point acupuncture (Ex+TrPAcp) significantly improved pain intensity more than exercise alone (Ex), with 6 of 7 patients in the Ex+TrPAcp group showing improvement compared to 1 of 7 in the Ex group.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years) with chronic low back pain lasting at least 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of physical activity interventions, including walking, in adults diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and explore potential effect moderators.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity, including walking, may improve IBS symptoms, but the evidence is very uncertain due to low certainty. No conclusive evidence was found for improvements in quality of life or abdominal pain, and adverse effects were poorly reported.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 or older diagnosed with IBS, primarily from high- or middle- to high-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how musical properties (familiarity, 'groove') and synchronization influence gait outcomes during rhythmic auditory stimulation (RAS) in younger and older adults with varying beat perception abilities.
results_summary: High groove music increased gait speed in both age groups, with longer strides in young adults, and synchronization enhanced these effects. Older adults with poor beat perception were more negatively affected by unfamiliar stimuli while walking compared to younger adults.
population_specificity: Younger and older adults with good and poor beat perception ability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of amifampridine in improving motor function in ambulatory patients with Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) Type 3.
results_summary: Amifampridine treatment led to a statistically significant improvement in the Hammersmith Functional Motor Score Expanded (HFMSE) compared to placebo, but no significant improvements were observed in secondary outcomes. The treatment was well-tolerated with only transient paresthesia reported as a side effect.
population_specificity: Ambulatory SMA Type 3 patients (aged 18-53, 38.5% female) not treated with SMN-enhancing medications.
effective_dosage: Optimized stable dose (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to assess the evidence basis for medications used for spine-related pain in older adults, focusing on drug metabolism and adverse drug reactions.
results_summary: The study did not evaluate Walking; it focused on medications like NSAIDs, gabapentinoids, SNRIs, and opioids for spine-related pain in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults (age >65 years) with spine-related pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in physical activity, particularly walking, among persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: Walking was the most frequently performed activity before the pandemic (27%) and increased during the pandemic (33%). The study noted a shift toward walking and wearable technology as preferred methods to stay active.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) (N=3725).
study_duration: Survey conducted from May to July 2021 (no specific intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of the Peer Empowerment Program 4 Physical Activity (PEP4PA) in increasing moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) and improving health outcomes in low-income older adults over a 2-year period.
results_summary: The intervention group sustained a 10-minute/day increase in MVPA and improved perceived quality of life (PQoL) scores, with greater improvements in males and higher-income groups. No significant effects were observed for the 6-Minute Walk Test or depressive symptoms, and blood pressure results were mixed.
population_specificity: Low-income older adults (50+ years, average age 71, 76% female, 60% low income, 38% racial/ethnic minorities).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included self-monitoring, health coaching, group walks, social support, and community advocacy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of home-based versus centre-based exercises on walking speed, balance, mobility, and participation in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study found high-quality evidence that home-based and centre-based exercises produce similar improvements in walking speed and balance, while results for mobility and participation were less precise. The effects remained comparable beyond the intervention period.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults at any time after stroke.
effective_dosage: Equivalent doses of home-based and centre-based exercises (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of a 12-week home-based telehealth exercise and behavioral intervention for improving clinical and health outcomes in socioeconomically deprived patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study will evaluate feasibility and acceptability outcomes, as well as secondary outcomes like functional capacity, quality of life, and lifestyle factors, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Socioeconomically deprived patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) in the UK.
effective_dosage: Home-based exercise twice a week and individual lifestyle program once per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term outcomes of lower versus higher oxygenation strategies in adult ICU survivors, including effects on cognitive function, health-related quality of life, and physical performance (6-min walk test).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in cognitive function or health-related quality of life between lower and higher oxygenation strategies. No data were available for the 6-min walk test or lung diffusion capacity.
population_specificity: Adult ICU survivors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize literature on objective walking activity measurements using wearable devices in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The review included 26 studies, with the ActiGraph GT3X being the most frequently used device. Walking activity was measured over periods ranging from 8 hours to one year, with 11 studies focusing on a 7-day monitoring period. The waist, ankle, and wrist were the most common sensor locations.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with Parkinson's disease (PD).
study_duration: Monitoring duration varied from 8 hours to one year, with 11 studies using a 7-day period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term effects of smoking on brain atrophy and clinical disability in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS).
results_summary: Smoking was associated with lower total white matter volume and greater disability progression after 10 years in RRMS patients. The findings suggest smoking cessation should be advised early after diagnosis to prevent long-term disability.
population_specificity: Treatment-naive patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and recent inflammatory disease activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether wearable motion sensors could provide valid measures to manage gait apraxia in idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH) patients.
results_summary: Instrumental variables from wearable sensors showed moderate to high correlation with clinical variables and significant improvements post-VPS, reflecting reduced gait apraxia. Most instrumental variables, unlike clinical ones, had predictive value for VPS outcomes.
population_specificity: 42 participants with idiopathic normal pressure hydrocephalus (iNPH) from the Bologna PRO-Hydro observational cohort study.
study_duration: Assessments at baseline, three days post-CSF-TT, and six months post-VPS.

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the safety and feasibility of transcatheter mitral cerclage ventriculoplasty in patients with mitral regurgitation and heart failure, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found improvements in mitral regurgitation and heart failure quality-of-life assessments, but no findings related to Walking were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with mitral regurgitation and heart failure (reduced or preserved ejection fraction).
study_duration: Median follow-up of 337 days for some outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if resistance exercise training (RET) improves cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Meta-analysis showed significant improvements in VO2 peak, aerobic threshold, and 6-minute walking distance test (6MWT) for RET interventions under 24 weeks, but no difference in longer interventions.
population_specificity: Healthy adults aged over 60.
study_duration: Less than 24 weeks for significant improvements; longer interventions showed no difference.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of community-based rehabilitation interventions incorporating outdoor mobility (primarily walking) on physical activity, endurance, outdoor mobility, and falls-related self-efficacy in older adults.
results_summary: Rehabilitation for reactive populations (illness/injury) increased physical activity, endurance, and outdoor mobility, with effects preserved at follow-up. One RCT showed benefits for proactive (community-dwelling) populations on moderate-to-vigorous activity and outdoor mobility, but no effect was noted for falls-related self-efficacy or other outcomes in proactive populations.
population_specificity: Older adults, divided into proactive (community-dwelling) and reactive (illness/injury) populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the minimal clinically important difference in the Berg Balance Scale and comfortable walking speed for acute-phase stroke patients undergoing rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that a change of 6.5-12.5 points in the Berg Balance Scale and 0.18-0.25 m/s in comfortable walking speed was required to be perceptible by patients and clinicians. These changes were considered clinically meaningful beyond measurement error.
population_specificity: Seventy-five acute-phase stroke patients with a mean age of 71.7 years.
effective_dosage: Physiotherapy sessions averaging 40 minutes/day on weekdays and 20 minutes/day on weekends and holidays.

study_goal: The researchers were evaluating the necessity of randomized trials for robotic-assisted walking training in patients with neurological injury and questioning the efficacy of current training parameters.
results_summary: The study suggests that robotic-assisted walking training may have inherent limitations due to flawed initial rationales and device design, leading to equivocal results regardless of training parameters. It also highlights lessons learned about critical parameters influencing neuromuscular and cardiovascular activity during training.
population_specificity: Patients with neurological injury

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the immediate and training effects of different attentional focus strategies (internal vs. external) on dual-task walking, freezing of gait (FOG), and falls in Parkinson's disease patients with and without FOG.
results_summary: External-focus improved walking automaticity and task accuracy in non-FOG participants, while internal-focus enhanced gait stability and reduced falling risk in FOG participants. Both focus strategies reduced FOG and falls after training, but only internal-focus improved timed up-and-go performance in both on- and off-medication states.
population_specificity: Parkinson's disease patients with (n=30) and without (n=16) freezing of gait (FOG).

study_goal: To explore the effect of hospital-family rehabilitation intervention on walking function and lower limb surface electromyography in children with cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The study group showed a higher effective rate (98.00%) compared to the control group (86.00%), with improved walking function and lower limb surface electromyography in children with cerebral palsy.
population_specificity: 100 children with cerebral palsy treated in a hospital from February 2019 to April 2021.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of exercise intervention (including walking) versus usual care on physical function biomarkers in older adults immediately after hospital discharge.
results_summary: The exercise intervention led to significantly greater improvements in physical function biomarkers compared to usual care, though sub-analyses for specific measures (e.g., handgrip strength, walking tests) did not show significant effects due to limited studies.
population_specificity: Older adults immediately after hospital discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tele-supervised home-based exercise training (including walking) improves cardiovascular, respiratory, and functional capacity in post-hospitalization COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: The exercise group showed improvements in arterial stiffness, oxygen saturation, and respiratory muscle strength, while both groups improved in lung function and handgrip strength. No significant changes were observed in other variables.
population_specificity: Individuals (52 ± 10 years, 17 female) hospitalized due to COVID-19.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review potential biases in QALY-based health technology assessments against non-ambulatory patients and investigate societal preferences for treating ambulatory versus non-ambulatory patients.
results_summary: The study found that non-ambulatory patients receive lower utility valuations, leading to lower QALY gains for treatments that do not restore ambulation, potentially making them seem less cost-effective. Societal preferences, however, favor equal treatment regardless of ambulatory status.
population_specificity: General public and non-ambulatory patients (e.g., those with advanced neuromuscular disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the measurement properties of performance-based measures for assessing physical function in people with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study identified the walk 40 m fast-paced test and 6-minute walking test as the best-rated walking tests for assessing physical function in knee osteoarthritis patients. The 30-second chair stand test and timed up and go test were the best-rated sit-to-stand tests.
population_specificity: People with knee osteoarthritis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of inspiratory muscle training (IMT) and calf muscle exercise training (CMET), combined with compression therapy (CT), on various health outcomes in patients with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) compared to CT alone.
results_summary: Group 2 (CMET plus CT) showed improvements in quality of life, venous refilling time, pain, edema, range of motion, muscle strength, and functionality. Group 1 (IMT plus CT) improved disease severity and inspiratory/expiratory muscle strength, while Group 3 (CT alone) only improved physical mobility and right leg venous refilling time.
population_specificity: 32 participants diagnosed with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze neurological and functional recovery (including walking function) in individuals with traumatic and ischemic spinal cord injury (SCI) over two decades, comparing international data and validating findings externally.
results_summary: The study found that neurological and functional recovery (including walking function) remained stable over 20 years despite changes in injury demographics and advances in clinical management. External validation confirmed these recovery profiles.
population_specificity: Individuals with acute traumatic and ischemic spinal cord injury (n=4601, with an external validation cohort of n=791).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of exercise interventions, including walking, on improving health-related physical fitness in adults with asthma.
results_summary: The study found that supervised aerobic exercise, including walking, significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness, functional fitness (walking distance), and overall health-related physical fitness in adults with asthma. Aerobic exercise was more effective than breathing/stretching exercises.
population_specificity: Adults aged 22 ± 4 to 71 ± 11 years with mild to severe asthma (n = 2135).
effective_dosage: Most common was supervised moderate-to-vigorous intensity aerobic exercise for 30-45 minutes, 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of individualized physiotherapy or treadmill training on gait during dual task performance in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Both physiotherapy and treadmill training significantly improved dual task gait speed (4.2% and 8.3%, respectively) and secondary gait parameters, UPDRS-III, BBS, and walking capacity, with no significant difference between interventions.
population_specificity: 105 patients with mild to moderate Parkinson's disease.
effective_dosage: 10 individual interventional sessions of 25 min each plus additional group therapy sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize quantitative research on outcomes associated with parkrun participation and factors influencing participation frequency and motivation.
results_summary: Limited evidence suggests parkrun participation improves fitness, BMI, physical activity levels, mood, and personal wellbeing. Motivators included fitness improvement and social interaction, with historical attendance strongly predicting future participation.
population_specificity: 18,203 participants across 11 studies, including individuals with non-running backgrounds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of long-term exercise therapy (≥12 weeks) for improving motor symptoms in patients with Parkinson disease, with a focus on optimizing improvements through exercise type and dose.
results_summary: Walking capacity outcomes did not improve after Tai Chi and resistance training but did improve after dance. The study found that increasing intervention duration or session length enhanced exercise effect sizes, with optimal benefits observed at a frequency of 2 times per week.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson disease (total of 1243 participants across 26 studies).
effective_dosage: Frequency of 2 times per week (optimal benefit).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if progressive functional resistance training (FRT) during walking improves knee biomechanical symmetry after ACL reconstruction and whether the mode of FRT delivery affects symmetry.
results_summary: The study found that 8 weeks of progressive FRT during treadmill walking improved knee angle and moment symmetry in individuals with ACL reconstruction, with the BAND group showing greater improvements in knee moment symmetry and the BRACE group showing significant improvements in knee angle symmetry.
population_specificity: Thirty individuals who underwent primary ACL reconstruction.
effective_dosage: Training sessions 2-3 times per week for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining transcranial direct-current stimulation (tDCS) with a footdrop stimulator (FDS) and gait training improves functional mobility in people with chronic hemiparesis after stroke.
results_summary: The study found no additional benefits from tDCS compared to sham tDCS when combined with FDS and gait training. Both groups showed improvements in functional mobility, reduced spasticity, increased quality of life, and walking endurance, with effects sustained at follow-up.
population_specificity: 32 individuals with mild, moderate, or severe chronic hemiparesis after stroke.
effective_dosage: 10 concurrent tDCS and FDS gait training sessions, 5 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether caffeine enhances the effects of acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH) on walking function in people with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI).
results_summary: The study found that pre-treatment with caffeine (an A2aR antagonist) before AIH improved walking function in participants with chronic iSCI, though the extent of this benefit in humans was unclear compared to prior rodent studies.
population_specificity: 12 participants with chronic (≥1 year) incomplete spinal cord injury (iSCI).
effective_dosage: 4 mg/kg caffeine daily, 30 minutes before AIH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the effectiveness of inpatient rehabilitation treatment ingredients, including walking-related interventions, on functioning, quality of life, and other outcomes for older adults with unplanned hospital admissions.
results_summary: Endurance exercise, early intervention, and shaping knowledge had large effects on walking endurance. Early intervention, repeated practice, and discharge planning increased the likelihood of discharge home, but rehabilitation interventions were ineffective for functional mobility, strength, quality of life, length of stay, or mortality.
population_specificity: Older adults with unplanned hospital admissions, including subgroups like those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or hip fracture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a specific oral nutritional supplement on nutritional status, functional recovery, and quality of life in COVID-19 survivors suffering from fatigue.
results_summary: The nutritional supplement significantly improved skeletal muscle index, handgrip strength, one-minute chair-stand test, six-minute walking test, and quality of life compared to the control group. All measured outcomes showed higher improvement in the treatment group after adjusting for age, gender, and baseline values.
population_specificity: COVID-19 survivors experiencing fatigue (66 participants, divided into intervention and control groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of omega-3 fatty acid supplementation, with or without resistance exercise training, on muscle mass and function, including walking performance, in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 fatty acid supplementation did not improve walking performance (SMD -0.01 [-0.10, 0.07]). Benefits were observed for lower body strength and functionality but not for walking.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥55 years without disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of Nordic walking (NW) with therapeutic climbing (CT) and a sedentary control condition on affective responses, anxiety, and self-efficacy in inpatients with mental health disorders.
results_summary: Nordic walking showed less favorable outcomes compared to therapeutic climbing in improving affective responses (positive affect, valence, activation) and reducing anxiety, though it was still part of the intervention. Self-efficacy increased significantly across interventions, but CT outperformed NW.
population_specificity: Inpatients (32 ± 12.2 years) with depression, anxiety, or obsessive-compulsive disorders.
study_duration: Single session per intervention (acute effects measured)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how patient characteristics and service provision influence changes in walking ability among heart failure patients undergoing cardiac rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found a mean improvement of 51.30 meters in walking distance post-rehabilitation. Female gender, retired status, being married/in a relationship, and higher BMI were significant negative predictors of improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure attending cardiac rehabilitation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the interactions between engineered nanomaterials (NMs) and biological barriers, focusing on how these interactions influence NM toxicity and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study discusses biological barriers NMs encounter and how these interactions can shift NM fate between toxicity and therapeutic effects, highlighting factors influencing NM access at the nano/bio interface.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on biological systems and nanomaterials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if lower limb mirror therapy improved muscle tone, motor function, balance, walking velocity, and gait characteristics in stroke patients compared to other interventions.
results_summary: Mirror therapy showed significant positive effects on motor function, balance capacity, walking velocity, ankle dorsiflexion range of motion, and step length in stroke patients, though methodological issues caution overly favorable interpretation.
population_specificity: Patients with stroke experiencing lower limb deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic therapeutic approaches for improving walking function in persons with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The study found that dalfampridine is the only FDA-approved pharmacologic agent improving walking in MS, while non-pharmacologic therapies like exercise and gait training also show efficacy. The review emphasizes the need for combinatory treatment approaches for optimal mobility restoration.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) experiencing mobility disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 12-week walking with breathing program on physical activity tolerance, oxygen saturation, interoceptive awareness, and psychosocial factors in heart failure patients.
results_summary: The walking with breathing program significantly improved 6-minute walk distance, oxygen saturation, and interoceptive awareness (specifically "Trusting"). It also reduced anxiety and improved quality of life, but did not significantly affect depression.
population_specificity: 90 heart failure patients
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved walking with breathing for 12 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess health-related quality of life and satisfaction with orthoses in children with arthrogryposis multiplex congenita who use orthoses for walking.
results_summary: Children dependent on orthoses for walking (Ort-D) showed lower physical functioning but were "quite satisfied" with their orthoses. No significant difference in perceived health was found between children using orthoses and those using only shoes.
population_specificity: Children with arthrogryposis multiplex congenita (n=33), divided into groups based on orthosis use (Ort-D, Ort-ND, Non-Ort).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review noninvasive methods for screening lower limb peripheral arterial disease (LLPAD), particularly in diabetic patients, and discuss their clinical effectiveness and limitations.
results_summary: The study highlights the use of noninvasive methods like ankle-brachial index (ABI), toe-brachial index (TBI), and photoplethysmogram (PPG) for LLPAD screening, emphasizing their cost-effectiveness and reduced pain compared to invasive methods. It also notes the increased risk of amputation in diabetic patients with severe LLPAD.
population_specificity: Patients with lower limb peripheral arterial disease (LLPAD), particularly those with type-2 diabetes.
